bibl.title: Letter from G.W. Gibson to The Marquis of Salisbury
Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

div1.p: Department of State Monrovia Liberia May 16 1879

My Lord Referring to my dispatch of Oct. 16th 1878, in which I informed your Lordship that the Liberian government had appointed two Commissioners to meet the mixed commission on the North Western boundary Question I have the honor to express the very deep request of His Exellency the President that the said commmission failed to accomplish the results so desired.

I need not stop here to give you a detailed account of the tedious
The Most Honourable The Marquis of Salisbury Foreign Office London

alleged to be giving to the tribes in the disputed territories. This govern ment cannot for amoment entertain the idea that their expectations will be realized, since it has long since been a matter of record that Great Britain acknowledges te of Liberia to all Territory between the " on the North West and the "San Pedro on the South East. Nor can I suppose for a moment that Great Britain would allow on the part of her officials or citizens any actions What would kin to our National Fabric. First I simply make this reference to show the effect that the attitude of HA government in connection with the North Western boundary

of the session yet believing that I aros from unavoidable causes they wave all complaint on that score. But where after the meeting of the Commission point arose upon which the Commission diagreed, this government fail to see upon what Grands HM Commission was refused to submit those points to the Arbitration of the United States government. This occurred first Sierra Leone whre a point of dis agreement arose, which in the financier of this governments should have been submitted to the NY Arbitrator for warded fufeldt; according to the terms of the Draft Proposals which has been suggested by H.M. Government and accepted by Liberia as the basis of the investigation to such a course
The Commissioners in the conviction of the justice of Our , and anxious for a settlement of the Question; yeilded.

An adjournment was agreed upon by the Mixed Commissions in of which they met at Sobymah on the 1st of April last. The result of eighteen days deliberation-during which the Commission examined the Title deeds of this government and took oral testimony of witnesses brought forward on the part of this govern ment as well as on behalf of the native Chiefs repduiating our claims to sovereignty-was another disappoint ments-The Liberia Commissions holding
holding that we had proved our title to the territories known as "," ", Rock & Rock" and "Solymah" and H.m. Commissioners averting that no such countries existed.

The Liberian Commissioners submitted that, according to the terms of the Draft Proposals, above, and the Instructions of both the English and Liberian Commissioners, the matter should be referred tot he American Arbitration for his decision.
This your Commissioners refused to do, their in- ability to do more than take the opinion of the American
